Notes from Liberian Legation In U.S. to Department of State, 1862-1898 T807

div1.p: Legation of the Republic of Liberia, Yonkers, N.Y. March 22nd, 1866

I see by the newspapaers that a Resolution has been offered in the House of Reperesentatives of the U.,S. "to discontinue an arrangement made with Great Britain to keep a naval force on the coast of Africa on the assumption that the slave trade has now ceased.

I have before me two tellers from Liberia recently received, one from W.J. Anderson dated 5th of Jany 1866 giving an account of a jourmey made last year about ninety miles (in a straight line) interiorward from Monrovia in whcih he says he found the native joins barricaded against wars which were there prevailing the sole object of which was the capture of men, women and children; the other from President Warner wa ging me to endeavor to by purchase on a or otherwise from the United States govenrment a small gun steam of not over one hun dred twenty tons and internally that the slave trade has not yet been suppressed by
within the lines of the Liberian Coast by the forces employed by America and England, but would be, if Liberia had such small vessel.
I beg leave to recall to your notice a part of the note which i had the honor to address to you on the 1st of Nov. last as follows.

"You are aware that hte late and lamented President Lincoln recommended to Congress to sell a small gun boat to Liberia; i have been inf -ed that a bill to do so was passed by one but that Congress adjourned before action on it was had in the other.

The United States having been at great in maintaining vessels on the coast of Africa, to suppress the slave trade, permit me to ask ( consideration of the fact that the use of a small boat by the government of Liberia would them more easily to keep 500 miles of the entirely free from that trade) whether the United States could consistently lend, until by act of Congress it could sell to Liberia on a credit, a gun boat of about one hundred tons, and there promote one of its own cherished objects to gret an extent, at so much smaller cost
can be effected in any other manner" Herewith please receive the late message of the President of Liberia; in it is mentioned a trety made with Portugal assimilitating the slave trade to piracy.
I have the honor to be, with the highest consideration Sir your most obedient servant Hm., Scheiffelir
Hon. Wm. H. Seward Secretary of State Washington D.C.
